726164f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726164f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, west from Vernon Boulevard, seen across the Long Island Railroad yards. The buildings are old tenements and are on the north side of the avenue, extending west to the East River. In the center, next to a pair of shacks, is the 4-story building of the Long JIsland Railroad branch of the Y.M.C.A. at the N.W. corner of Fifth Street. Across the latter is the Pennsylvania Railroad power house, at 51st Avenue and Second Street. The mid-Manhattan skyline, with the Chrysler building prominently visible, is in the background. View 2 shows the north side of the avenue. On the left is the Empire State Building. View 3 shows the south side of the avenue and the old Long Island City railroad station, on 2nd
Street.
P. L. Sperr  August 25, 1936
NO REPRODUCTIONS  Views 1,2,3
726164f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726160f-b.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726160f-b.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, east from Vernon Boulevard, showing the Thompson lumber yard. All structures along the avenue were later torn down and the plaza of the CueensMidtown Tunnel constructed here.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726160f-b.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726159f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726159f-a.text:
10-17 Borden Avenue, north side, just east of Vernon Boulevard. This building,among others, was Pazed to make way for the construction of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel plaza. To its
right is the M.H. Thompson lumber yard.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726159f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726161f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726161f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, between Vernon Boulevard and 11th Street, showing the interior of M.H. Thompson's lumber yard. The view is eastward and shows the rears of houses fronting on the south side of 51st Avenue. The lumber yard and the dwellings were later obliterated and the CueensMidtown Tunnel plasa was erected here. The view marks the direct line of the new road from where later will be the exit
from the tunnel.
November 21, 1938
New ork City Tunnel Authority
726161f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726162f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726162f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, south side, east from Vernon Boulevard, showing the Long Island Railroad yards in the immediate neighborhood of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726162f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726163f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726163f-a.text:
Borden Avenue, north side, east from Vernon Boulevard. All structures, extending as far as the water tank in front of the white factory building, were later torn down and the area converted into the sunken plaza of the GCueens-Midtown Tunnel. Note the M.H. Thompson lumber yard in the center.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
726163f-a.folder: Borden Avenue & Vernon Boulevard, Queens, NY

726942f-a.title: Queens: Jackson Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726942f-a.text:
Jackson Avenue, north side, at Vernon Boulevard, near the OQueens-Midtown Tunnel plama. The vehicular
viaduct is on Vernon Boulevard.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority

726156f-a.title: Queens: Borden Avenue - Vernon Boulevard
726156f-a.text:
10-11 Borden Avenue, adjoining the N.E. corner of Vernon Boulevard. This house, as well as all others on the block, were later torn down to make way for the construction of the sunken plana of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. On the left is the rear of the Clay Building, on dackson Avenue. This site, below
street level, marks the tunnel's exit.
November 17, 1938
New York City Tunnel Authority
